review_title: No Respect for Workers, Boring, Flexible
job_title: Front Desk Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: This position offered flexibility with my classes and the job was easy. Aside from the people aspect of it, this job was considerably easy. Requires no heavy lifting, little moving or exercise, and is not an intellectually demanding job.
cons: Workers are not allowed to utilize times where they have no work to listen to music, do homework, read, or draw. Workers are expected to sit in a chair and face forward for hours on end with no human interaction, even into the late hours of the night and early morning. Workers are paid minimum wage and are expected to deal with dangerous situations, security risks, parent complaints, police, constantly breaking equipment, and extremely rude students. Furthermore, there is little to no support from FDSMs, as they do not offer much leeway. The position is brain numbingly boring and a waste of time, unless you enjoy getting cursed at by drunk college students regularly.

review_title: Good to get your foot in the door, terrible for long-term career
job_title: Administrative Support Coordinator II in San Diego, CA
pros: Very chill until it gets insanely busy; might help a recent grad that wants to get the foot in the administrative world, I always recommend people to stay here six months to two years max and then find something else that pays more; lots of well-meaning people stuck in low-paying jobs; great coworkers; decent health/dental/car insurance benefits; students are very nice and easy to work with
cons: The structure; the politics; SDSU does not prioritize staff salaries or staff well-being in general; salaries are low for the cost of living; expectations are ludicrous for the pay; very difficult to obtain a raise; if you stay here for years, your salary WILL become stagnant which cannot keep up with the cost of living on the long-term (aka, you're losing money); people constantly leaving so it's hard to get things done or someone has to pick up the slack; don't expect much or any telework if that's a priority of yours; little to no staff development; training is practically non-existent, you have to rely on the people that have been there the longest, good luck if your team is brand new; a lot of processes take a very long time to process, and many people will ask you for things last minute and expect them to be done ASAP, which is not realistic

job_title: Administrative Coordinator II in San Diego, CA
pros: IF you get a good manager, you can feel fulfilled (to a certain point) by your work and your team, even the students you support (if you do that). There are a lot of initiatives in the works right now for diversity, equity and inclusion, as well as bettering the campus climate.
cons: IF you get a bad manager, work is grueling, faculty microaggress or bully you without consequence, and you feel isolated and unsupported or not valued. On top of which you are NOT properly compensated for your work and dedication, or growing expertise. You have to make sure to do the work with your union to put your managers in their place when they step out of line (again, usually without any real consequence) and if you want to get higher degrees and better professional development, the only way to be recognized in pay is to leave the job you put time and effort into learning, for another job somewhere else on campus that pays more and is a higher level. Good benefits BECAUSE of the unions!

job_title: Director, Program Management in San Diego, CA
pros: Great benefits of being a State Employee, difficult to move up into higher positions. Currently there are a lot of changes so there are lay-offs without filling positions. I have a great boss, however there is still a lot of bureaucracy (although you'll find this at any organization) It seems like their goal is revenue rather that student experience. If you are in charge of running programs, you have limited resources and support from upper management. There is definitely, favoritism, ageism, and sexism. Unless you are covered by one of the unions, there is less chance of you getting a raise. Foundation employees do not match raises that state employees get. These are all things that you will most likely experience at some point in a job position you take elsewhere. No office is perfect but if you are looking to apply to a position, check and ask them directly if there is potential to move up and also ask what their 'company culture' is. Other than that, I feel fortunate to have a good boss. If you have a good boss, they are flexible with your schedule which helps a great deal
cons: Low pay if you are in a  lower position, currently there is a lot of disorganization and many people are in fear of loosing there jobs, at times there is high turnovers. New management, lots of change that is not always good.  Sometimes there is low moral

job_title: Student Network Technician in San Diego, CA
pros:
* If you're a student, they have to be flexible with your scheduling. They know your education comes first.
* Everybody in your department has the same pay, so everybody is on the same page regarding that.
* Overall, everybody is nice and helpful as long as you do your job.
* Student workers get paid better in the technology departments than others like Aztec Shops. There were talks of salary going from $10/hr to $12 in January.
cons:
* Student workers are hired "at-will," meaning supervisors can fire you with no notice and no real reason. 
* The ETS department is so mired in internal politics that your supervisors are scared to do anything that might get them noticed by THEIR supervisors.
* Limited working hours, can't work on weekends. When there are no classes in session, you can work full time which is GREAT - but if you take even one class over the summer, you are automatically pushed back to 20 hours.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Associate in San Diego, CA
pros: The people at San Diego State are wonderful, there is a real collaborative community environment. There is a lot of freedom within your assigned course to teach material that inspires you. Typically Fall courses are easier to come by. The campus (despite the thousands that enroll) is rather compact and easy to get from one side to the other---no buses, etc. necessary. Oh, and the weather!
cons: If you are an inexperienced teacher, there isn't much training to set you up for success (this does depend on the department, however, as some are much more thorough than others). Also, it is rather difficult to get enough classes to earn benefits or any other such perks and the pay is far less than an adjunct despite the fact that you're doing the same work. Teachers also pay for parking and do not get discounts at on campus dining or stores.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Everyone I interacted with on a personal basis at the University was friendly, professionally, and helpful. Most of my work involved reviewing assignments (first for a Freshman English class and then doctoral dissertation drafts), which could occasionally become tedious, yet I was able to do this work on my own time and in my own way, so long as it did in fact get done. Thus, this was a great job that allowed me to work around my student schedule while still paying enough to make living in Southern California affordable (no easy feat!) All in all, it's a great place to work, full of great people.
cons: SDSU's bureaucracy is one of the worst I've ever encountered, as it is composed of lots of little compartmentalized departments that essentially never communicate with one another. None of this is the fault of any of the individuals working within the system, yet the structure of the institution itself can be extremely frustrating to deal with, as both a student and an employee.

review_title: College of Extended Studies: Salary not that great - chill atmosphere
job_title: Program Coordinator in San Diego, CA
pros: If you work for SDSU you are most likely a State Employee. Benefits are great, I don't have to pay for health insurance, I have retirement, I have a union and have somewhat of good vacation / sick time available. Our office is super chill. I'm not stressed out. Majority of people are very nice and relaxed. Hard to get fired if you have a union : ) If you are State employee you can get your school paid for. Very flexible if you have a dr.appointment or need a flexible schedule. NOTE: This may very per each department on campus.
cons: Pay is very little, very difficult to move into a new position or ask for a raise. Like many places, there can be bureaucracy within the office. Need more transparency and loyalty to employees. Very high turnover - mostly due to pay, for example UCSD pays much more than SDSU for same positions.

job_title: Aquaplex Lifeguard in San Diego, CA
pros: As a lifeguard at the Aztec Aquaplex, I enjoy the loose hours. Only working 20 hours per week and working around my schedule is very helpful. During finals, I can work as much as I want or none at all. Free membership to the ARC is an added bonus. All the workers are very friendly, and Jake, the boss is super accommodating. If you need help with anything he will do his best to figure out a solution.
cons: The issue with working at the Aquaplex is that the rules are very inconsistent. Depending on who is the "lead lifeguard" scheduled, you could be doing a ton of annoying busywork during your break, or none at all. It is very frustrating to have such inconsistent leadership. Also there is not much upward mobility.

job_title: President/Chief Executive Officer in San Diego, CA
pros:
- Opportunities are here to grow your networks, work with students, faculty, staff and administration
- Always have a seat at the table with higher ups
- If you want to get something done, staff and students work together to pull together resources to make visions into realities
- Relationship building is crucial to success as a student leader
- great work/ life balance, flexible schedule
- awesome support system
cons:
- Culture tends to be laid back, but allows you to work at your own pace
- A lot of the work done in AS is self-motivated, need to build a team of people to keep one another accountable, but the team may not always be on board
- a lot of individual personalities that sometimes get in the way of organizations greater goal

job_title: Student Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Working in the Student Life and Leadership Department of Student Affairs gave you a great overall picture on how the campus actual runs not only as an educational institution, but also as a business. The people are friendly and supportive in your collegiate efforts.
cons: At times the issues or projects you might be working on would hit a little close to home; as with any campus job keeping work and school separated is something you would need to strive to do no matter where you work.

review_title: So much room for professional growth!
job_title: Student Services Professional 1B in San Diego, CA
pros: On-the-job training is the best I've ever had! Good work/life balance. Lots of opportunities for growth with professional development days, workshops, trainings, etc. As SDSU staff, occasionally there are projects that require interdepartmental collaborations and it helps with the networking. Exciting to be a part of a university that continues to grow and make a strong community and global impact.
cons: Because the university is so large, it can be hard to get connected or to feel like your voice can be heard outside of your union. Staff/Faculty must pay for their own parking. No food perks. Currently, there is no GSI or salary steps in place, so it's not clear how easy it will be to get promoted.

review_title: Solid care to students with disabilities
job_title: Tutor in San Diego, CA
pros: One of my positions with SDSU was tutoring for student disabled services. Overall, I feel the staff was passionate and involved regarding the needs of the students. Staff seemed willing to listen to students and do their best to assist students in accessing all available resources.
cons: A limited number of the staff members seemed lethargic and un-involved. There seems to be little recourse to get these people out of these positions. Their presence seemed to offer more of a hindrance, rather than a help, to these students so in need.

review_title: There are extremely limited opportunities for individual and/or career development.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Best reason to work for the CSU system is for the benefits.  Yet, those are rapidly changing.  The campus environment is beautiful.
cons: Pay is non-competitive and often downright dismal.  There are very few pay increases.  Even when you develop a solid argument for a pay increase, it's shot down due to budget.  Collective bargaining agreement job classifications stranglehold those employees trying to get ahead, but can't.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Associate in San Diego, CA
pros: Organized HR department and great compensation package. For many positions, there is room for advancement and there are plenty of opportunities for staff involvement. As a teaching associate, work-life balance can be tough. I was lucky enough to be surrounded by staff who made an effort to achieve that balance and to encourage others to do so as well.
cons: In a teaching associate position, working with difficult students was challenging. However, I never felt like I had to deal with said students by myself, I always had assistance. The hours can also be long during "peak" academic weeks, but those times were balanced out by long vacation periods. San Diego State is a great place to work!

review_title: No career advancement or professional growth opportunities. Do not value their employees.
job_title: Administrative Support Coordinator in San Diego, CA
pros: Benefits - but those are sure to go away in the next year or two. New employees are already in a separate category where their benefits are not fully covered. Not a good enough reason to work here.
cons: SDSU does not like to develop it's people or advance them in their careers. They do not give raises or any living wage increase. Moral is low due to apathetic attitudes by management. Leadership is non-existent. HR is not your friend - they strictly uphold the rules. Innovation is below dismal even though it's one of SDSU's top initiatives in their fundraising campaign.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bellingham, WA
pros: Good experience, and enjoyable most of the time to work with students.  Are able to teach the labs the way we want to, just have to follow the schedule.
cons: Extra assignment of working with lecture professor is less then ideal.  Some don't require their TAs to do anything, but others work the TAs extra hard and expect you to very simple tasks.  If possible, get an extra assignment to teach a third lab.  Less work than working with a professor.

job_title: Student Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: The department I worked with was filled with courteous and good-humored people who enjoyed working with each other and helping clients. Everyone is easy to talk to, and there is zero drama at work. The campus is constantly adding new restaurants that are only a 10-minute walk away from the office which is a huge plus when your lunch is only 30 minutes.
cons:
- Lunch is only 30 minutes
- You get paid monthly
- There is a noticeable power hierarchy and you are always reporting to a supervisor

job_title: Research Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Very healthy student on-campus job.  The pay rate, time given etc. is extremely satisfactory. The student mentor relationship is active and one can grow within the field of research especially. All requirements for a project are sanctioned immediately and the backing you get from the professors is very good.
cons: There can be an instance of going overboard with the work and that affecting your regular curriculum but that is only if you are clocking more than the number of hours you can actually handle.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Associate in San Diego, CA
pros: Pick own schedule- i would typically work 1-3 nights a wk 20% Discount 33% discount twice a year Easy job Started at 11.20/hr. they have a 4 step oay scale for hourly employees- customers are typically cool if you like fast pace, this is the job for you volume depends on store, a busy location means…
cons: weekends are not ideal but expected in retail they want you to open cards but you get 5$ for opening a card sometimes closing can be for 1.5 hours after the store closes (11:30pm) shirts are bright green the rally's in the am are funny

job_title: Resident Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Very impactful experience to help residents at SDSU. I have grown as a leader, and have learned valuable leadership and adaptability skills. Also, compensation is great...depending on the building you work at. My boss and coworkers each year have been amazing!
cons: Odd hours. Depending on what building you get placed in you will have more or less work to do. The department has many requirements that they do not tell you up front. Shorter summer break because of long all day training session in the fall.  Everyone has a very different experience depending on the boss, coworkers, and problem residents.

review_title: Easy, fun job! Ideal for students.
job_title: Event Staff
pros: Healthy and laid back work environment, opportunity to see athletic events and concerts, job rotation, meal coupons, first come first serve shift scheduling - sign up to work the events and shifts that fit your schedule.
cons: Minimum wage, having to stand in one place for long periods of time, dealing with difficult/rowdy guests, noise, irregular/sporadic work hours, not much opportunity for growth beyond House Manager and Event Staff Supervisor.

job_title: Lecturer in San Diego, CA
pros: Wherever you work, the people you work with and the social environment are key to being happy in one's job. What can I say: I get paid to have fun explaining how all the cool techno-toys work while playing with them! All the faculty, staff and administrators I've interacted with at SDSU are very easy to work with. The vast majority care deeply about education and the students, and are there because they have an honest desire to help a very diverse student population with a large contingent of first in the family to go to college. From janitor to President, the people I've interacted with at SDSU are overwhelmingly good people.
cons: Funding is usually the limiting factor. Nobody is a teacher for the money! It is a very large, very old institution that comes with the usual big state funded organization's characteristics, like most any public university, but the people seem far more sincere and down to earth than some other universities. Two independent studies have shown that for every $1 per year the state spends on UC and CSU, there's a return of about $5 from increased annual personal state income tax and reduced expenses like unemployment. That's not including the businesses that pay taxes and bring jobs to the state.. In spite of this >500% ROI, the state spends only about $7K on every student, but $74K on every prisoner every year!

review_title: Great place to get experience teaching basic writing skills
job_title: Teaching Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: I was an MFA candidate but I also wanted to gain experience as a teacher. They certainly have a great system for training students to become teachers of rhetoric and writing.
cons: Pay is not so great, and you have to take seminar, which requires credits which requires money, your first semester, but the seminar is extremely helpful in getting you through till finals.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: The best reason to work for San Diego State University is that they work around your school schedule. It is also a plus to work close to home and where you are learning.
cons: There are not a lot of negatives to working for the college. One big one is the funding for student workers that affects the total number of hours you can work in any given week.

job_title: Teaching Associate in San Diego, CA
pros: The area and weather are unbeatable. The university is also of sufficient size to offer a range of opportunities for staff involvement. The benefits package is also respectable.
cons: No bike racks. There are some, but they are poorly designed and insufficient. The salary for teaching associates is insufficient to live off of, you will need to have another job, although you will already be taking class as well as teaching.

job_title: Desk Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: The work is very accomidating to a student's schedule.  Since the desks are in the residence halls, most students do not have to travel far to get to work, and can get by showing up in your pajamas.
cons: The pay is absolute minimum wage.  Most of the supervisors are students themselves, and do not really care much for the worker's wellbeing.

review_title: A Nice Place to Get a Job While You're a Student There
job_title: Writing Fellow in San Diego, CA
pros: Flexible hours and lots of friendly people. I worked for the Rhetoric and Writing Centre and I gained a lot of experience working with students and professors. All of this was helpful to my future career aspirations.
cons: Can take time away from studying if you're a student though by helping other students with their strategies you can also gain insight into your own.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: The majority of work done was holding office hours and grading exams, both of which I enjoyed. You're given a lot of freedom when it comes to choosing your office hours and how you teach -- there's not very much oversight and the choice is mostly yours. Good review experience before applying to full-time jobs.
cons: Not many downsides, I'd recommend it to anyone who's most of the way through their degree and wants to work part-time in their field. Getting paid is a hassle but otherwise no complaints.

review_title: Excellent opportunities to grow, but not within this system: plan to take gained skills elsewhere
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Great learning experience and those in the organization are eager and willing to train and teach. (Imagine that! In a school!) Dedicated faculty and staff are a pleasure to work with and for; their commitment to the students is admirable and inspiring.
cons: Bureaucracy of a educational system in deep trouble and all jobs below administration seem to be on the verge of being cut. Makes for a very tense atmosphere rife with competition and uncompensated hours spent outside of the classroom.

review_title: Working as a Research associate at San Diego State University
job_title: Research Associate in San Diego, CA
pros: Great work environment based on labs and research meetings to discuss the progression of the research project and set goals to finish the project in a timely manner.
cons: Long working hours at the lab and there is no Cafeteria or a break room  nearby the lab or  the building to have your break because you are nor allowed to enter food or drinks inside the lab and sometimes you can not leave the lab work unattended to go for your break.

job_title: Research Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Everyone at San Diego State University is amazing and brilliant. They have state of the art facilities and you can get an amazing opportunity to conduct research as a graduate student for a very low cost annually for a masters degree and they offer very good phd level degrees.
cons: One con for going to San Diego State University is the fact that the school is a commuter campus, so one may not feel that the campus has the sense of school pride as many people do not live at the actual school.

review_title: Great school, great community, great faculty!
job_title: Resident Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: School is growing and going through a lot of changes and improvement. Increasing acceptance rate every year. A lot of opportunities to get involved and strengthen leadership skills. Good variety of food options all around campus.
cons: Not providing a lot of classes that caters to the amount of students at the school. The waitlist system was horrible, I was held back a semester because there wasn’t enough space in a class that I needed.

job_title: IT Consultant in San Diego, CA
pros:
Great work/life balance.  As staff you will not work more than 40 hours a week on average.
Very diverse work force.
Great state benefits
Beautiful Campus and weather
cons:
CA Budget problems causing lay offs and furloughs
Parking is a serious pain.  In addition to that everyone has their car broken into at SDSU.  It is just a fact of life there.

review_title: SDSU is a nice place to work
job_title: LSSIII Specialist in San Diego, CA
pros: Diversity and inclusion strongly supported.  Neither age nor sex/gender seems to matter.  Nice people in the Library.  Climate changing but beautiful spot and mild weather.  If you like surfing or beaches, it's perfect.  They are somewhat flexible as to work/life balance.

job_title: Information Services in San Diego, CA
pros: Working at the ARC at SDSU is a great job for students. Work schedule is very flexible and working with your peers is a bonus. Overall, good for anyone looking for 10-20 hours a week.
cons: Not too much downside. The pay is min wage, but its a student job. At times, can be boring during slow times

job_title: Music Director in San Diego, CA

cons: No pay for any position at the student ran radio station. Not much help from faculty therefore the students have to hold events or recruit student fee to get any funding. Faculty is there to make sure you'r following the rules but to expand the organization is almost non existant

review_title: Laid back culture that allowed me to manage school and work.
job_title: Lifeguard in San Diego, CA

-huge organization

-co workers were fun and outgoing that turned into lasting relationships

cons:
-clicks between coworkers were formed
-manager was way to laid back, didnt enforce rules to the people who broke them
-unruly people were rarely fired

review_title: Great community, decent benefits, not much pay.  When people get a job here, they stay
job_title: Health in San Diego, CA

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA

Great student perks. Minimal responsibility, able to do homework on the job if its not busy.

job_title: Student Assistant in San Diego, CA

job_title: Academic Mentor in San Diego, CA

review_title: I love teaching; I abhor the disrespect and lack of advancement for lecturers
